description: The USE Method based on Node Dashboard for the Prometheus Node Exporter

panels.description:
CPU Busy

The fraction of time that the CPU is busy. A high percentage (close to 100%) indicates that the system is running low on available CPU resources.

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.title: CPU Utilisation

panels.description:
System Load

The degree to which the extra workload will be queued using load averages as a proxy.

Load Average

The metric represents the n-minute load average. The load average is the average number of jobs in the run queue (state R) or waiting for disk I/O (state D) over the last n-minutes.

Run Queue Length

The number of tasks in the runnable or uninterruptible state. A high run queue length can indicate CPU saturation.

CPU I/O Wait

The amount of time the CPU is idle due to waiting to handle I/O operations. High I/O wait times can indicate CPU saturation.
panels.title: CPU Saturation

panels.description:
NOTE The metrics are just proxies for errors and may not indicate an actual error state. Always interpret these metrics in the context of the system performance and other indicators.

Context Switches

The metric represents the total number of context switches. A context switch is the action of storing the state of a process or of a thread so that execution can be resumed from the same point at a later time. High rates of context switching can indicate inefficient scheduling or  contention for CPU resources.

Steal Time

In virtualized environments, "steal time" refers to the time that a virtual CPU waits for a real CPU while the hypervisor is servicing another virtual processor.

Soft Lockups

A soft lockup is the symptom of a task or kernel thread using and not releasing a CPU for a period of time.

Guest Time

In virtualized environments, this refers to the time a CPU was busy executing a virtual CPU for guest operating systems under the control of the Linux kernel.
panels.title: CPU Error

panels.description:
RAM

The fraction of time that the memory is being used. A high demand (close to 100%) indicates that the system is running low on available memory.

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.title: Memory Utilisation

panels.description:
SWAP

The degree to which the extra workload will be queued using swap usage as a proxy. The metric represents the number of memory pages that have been read/written from the swap space into the memory. Consistently high values for this metric could indicate that the system is under memory pressure.

Memory Buffer Size

If the buffer size is decreasing, it could indicate memory pressure.

matcher.options: Hardware Corrupted - Amount of RAM that the kernel identified as corrupted / not working

panels.title: Memory Saturation

panels.description:
OOM Killer

The Out-Of-Memory (OOM) killer is a process that the Linux kernel employs when the system is critically low on memory. Values consistently above zero, means the system is frequently running out of memory. System kills of processes due to insufficient memory, it's a strong indicator of memory errors.

Memory Page Faults

The number of major faults the system has made due to the fact that not enough memory was available, resulting in disk swap in/out operations. This is often a symptom of the system not having enough memory, which can be considered a form of memory error.
panels.title: Memory Error

panels.description:
Traffic Bandwidth

The metric is a counter that represents the total number of bytes received/transmitted on the network interface. High rates can indicate that the network interface is heavily utilized.

Packet Rate

The rate of packets sent or received can be indicative of network utilization.
panels.title: Network Utilisation

panels.description:
Receive/Transmit Drop

The metric is a counter that represents the total number of received/transmitted packets that were dropped. Dropped packets could indicate network saturation.

Transmit Queue Length

Indicates if the network interface is saturated. A growing queue length can indicate higher saturation levels.
panels.title: Network Saturation

panels.description:
Receive/Transmit Errors

The metric is a counter that represents the total number of receive/transmit errors encountered by the network device. The errors could be due to various reasons such as faulty hardware, network congestion, or packet corruption. Error counts can be a sign of network problems.
panels.title: Network Error

panels.description:
I/O Busy

The metric represents the total number of seconds spent doing I/O operations. A high rate indicates that the system is spending a lot of time performing disk I/O operations, which could be a sign of a bottleneck.
panels.title: Disk I/O Utilisation

panels.description:
NOTE The metrics are just proxies for saturation and may not indicate an actual saturation state. Always interpret these metrics in the context of the system performance and other indicators.

I/O Wait Time

The time operations had to wait for disk access.
panels.title: Disk I/O Saturation

panels.description:
NOTE The metrics are just proxies for errors and may not indicate an actual error state. Always interpret these metrics in the context of the system performance and other indicators.

I/O Queue Operations

The number of queued operations that are waiting to be completed represented as the number of read/write errors.
panels.title: Disk I/O Error

panels.description:
Disk Space

The metric provides the number of bytes available in the filesystem. It shows how much free space is left that can be utilized.
panels.title: Storage Utilisation

panels.description:
NOTE The metrics are just proxies for saturation and may not indicate an actual saturation state. Always interpret these metrics in the context of the system performance and other indicators.

File Nodes

The metric indicates the number of free inodes in the filesystem. Inodes are data structures used to store information about files and directories.
panels.title: Storage Saturation

panels.description:
NOTE The metrics are just proxies for errors and may not indicate an actual error state. Always interpret these metrics in the context of the system performance and other indicators.

Disk Filesystem Error

The metric counts the number of errors encountered by the filesystem device. Errors can occur due to various reasons such as hardware issues, permission problems, or configuration errors.
panels.title: Storage Error

title: USE Method
